icon.heading: Lifts
icon.description: Your transport up the slopes

icon.heading: Novice Trails
icon.description: Gentle groomed slopes for beginners

icon.heading: Advanced Beginner
icon.description: Click this icon to see the double green runs - Gentle groomed slopes for beginners - steeper than novice trails

icon.heading: Intermediate Trails
icon.description: Click this icon to see the blue runs - Moderately sloped trails that are challenging in some places

icon.heading: Advanced Intermediate
icon.description: Click this icon to see the dble. blue runs - more challenging than intermediate trails

icon.heading: Advanced Trails
icon.description: Click this icon to see the black runs - Steeply sloped trails that are challenging from top to bottom

icon.heading: Expert Trails
icon.description: Click this icon to see the dble. black runs - Trails include cliffs, chutes and cornices suitable for experts only

icon.heading: Permanently Closed
icon.description: Permanently closed due to cliffs, avalanche hazards and potential loss of life. Do not ski here.

icon.heading: Slow Skiing Areas
icon.description: Click this symbol to show areas designated for slow skiing and snowboarding

icon.heading: Area Information
icon.description: Area names and descriptions

icon.heading: Terrain Parks
icon.description: Click this icon to see where our man made obstacles for jumping and sliding are placed -

icon.heading: Recently Groomed Trails
icon.description: Click this symbol to see which trails have been groomed the past 24 hrs

icon.heading: Web Cams
icon.description: Click on one of these web cam icons to view images from fixed locations taken within the last hour

icon.heading: Videos
icon.description: Videos of skiers and snowboarders in action from around the resort

icon.heading: Photos
icon.description: Click to view photos of skiers and snowboarders in action from around the resort

icon.heading: 360 Panoramas
icon.description: Click this icon to see 360-degree views of locations around the mountain

icon.heading: Lodging
icon.description: Places to stay on and around the ski resort

icon.heading: Dining
icon.description: Food and/or bar facilities for breakfast, lunch and dinner

icon.heading: Retail Stores
icon.description: Sunblock to goggles, everything you need for a day on the snow

icon.heading: Rentals
icon.description: Ski and snowboard equipment rental shop

icon.heading: Ski & Ride School
icon.description: Meeting place for ski and snowboard lessons

icon.heading: Information
icon.description: Mountain and surrounding area pamphlets and information

icon.heading: Transport
icon.description: Free road transport to, from and around the ski resort.

icon.heading: Telephones
icon.description: Public coin and card telephones

icon.heading: Parking
icon.description: Parking lots allocated for ski area users

icon.heading: Rest Rooms
icon.description: Toilet facilities for men and women

icon.heading: First Aid
icon.description: Basic first aid kits for minor injuries

lift.description:
This center of Telluride lift is

your avenue to some of the most challening skiing Telluride has to offer.

As with every lift on the mountain, Apex links you to intermediate terrain and is downloadable.
lift.heading: Oak Street Lift (8)

lift.description:
Coonskin, the west-end of

town access, is the original town of

Telluride lift. It has a convenient drop-off for terrain on both sides of the mountain, skiing to Mountain Village, and is the meeting point for Mountain Tours.
lift.heading: Coonskin Lift (7)

lift.description:
Linking Telluride to Mountain

Village, the Gondola is the only transportation system of its kind in North America. Running daily from

7 am to midnight, the 13-minute gondola ride eliminates the 20-minute, 8-mile drive between both towns. The gondola operates year-round, with temporary off-season closures.
lift.heading: Free Gondola

lift.description:
This Gondola is conveniently

located to transport you from the free Mountain Village Intercept parking lot to the village core, the Ski & Snowboard School, and the base of Village Express Lift.

The Mountian Village Intercept parking lot is also ski-in/ski-out, accessable from lower Double Cabin ski runs. Also located at the Intercept parking is the Mountain Village Market & Liquor.
lift.heading: Free Intercept Gondola

lift.description:
The Chondola is a combination

pedestrain transportaion and ski chair lift taking you between the Village core and BIg Billies restaurant.

This 5 minute ride is a great opportunity for non-skiers to watch friends & family ski before joining them at Big Billies.
lift.heading: Chondola (1)

lift.description:
This Pomma lift is used for

access to the advanced 2 Park terrain park.
lift.heading: 2 Park Lift

lift.description:
This main artery out of the

Mountain Village core delivers skiers to terrain of every ability level.

Village Express connects you to runs on the front face of the mountain, the meeting point for Mountain Tours, routes to the Plunge and Polar Queen lifts, as well as access to Telluride's largest dining facility, Gorrono Ranch.
lift.heading: Village Express (4)

lift.description:
The Plunge Lift completes

your route to one of the most spectacular 360-degree views in North America. With Bushwhacker, Kant-Mak-M and the Plunge dropping from its pinnacle, no lift on the mountain gives you a better sense of freedom than the Plunge lift.

Meet up with friends and get re-energized with a black bean saute and the best view ever at Giuseppe's.
lift.heading: Plunge Lift (9)

lift.description:
Originally Telluride's highest

lift, this gully lift gives you access to some of the tightest bump runs and gladed tree skiing on the mountain. As with every lift on the mountain, Apex links you to intermediate terrain and is downloadable.
lift.heading: Apex Lift (6)

lift.description:
The Polar Queen Express is

Telluride's best access to every type of intermediate terrain on the mountain. Whether you're looking to improve from groomed to bumps, try your hand at powder skiing, or check out some trees, this lift offers it all at an intermediate level.

Polar Queen takes you to 1 of 2 portals for Prospect Basin and access to the Apex Lift.
lift.heading: Polar Queen Express (5)

lift.description:
Your first run into Revelation

Bowl will be coming off Gold Hill Express, a five minute ride from

Prospect Basin to the Gold Hill Ridge. This lift accesses Revelation Bowl and some of the steepest skiing in North America as well as the world famous intermediate run, See Forever, where the view of Utah's La Sal mountain range 90 miles to the west is something to experience in person.
lift.heading: Gold Hill Express (14)

lift.description:
After your first run through

Telluride's newest terrain, stop off at the Bear Creek Overlook to take in this unique view before loading Telluride's newest lift up to 12,570'.
lift.heading: Revelation Lift (15)

lift.description:
This high speed quad is your

access to some of the highest elevation beginner and intermidiate glade skiing in North America. This also takes you the

hike-to terrain of

Black Iron Bowl

and 11,540'

Palmyra Peak.
lift.heading: Prospect Express (12)

lift.description:
Looking for your skate from

Prospect Basin? This is it! This 3 minute pomma lift ride takes you from Prospect Basin to the Ute Park Terrain with as little effort as possible.
lift.heading: Lynx (13)

lift.description:
Are you new to the sport of

skiing and just wish you had your own private lift to learn on? Ute Park is the place for you! Enjoy the lift and runs to yourself as this gentle terrain is the gem of the resort. Whether you are new to skiing or are feeling confident enough in your snowboarding skills that you want to test your abilities in a terrain park, Ute Park will seem as though it belongs to you.
lift.heading: UTE Park (11)

lift.description:
Sunshine Express is your

ticket to the wide open terrain of beginner and intermediate runs which also serve as access the beautiful homes of Mountain Village.
lift.heading: Sunshine Express (10)

lift.description:
Meadows Magic Carpet is the

ideal location for the Never-Ever skier. Easy to get to and out of the way of the main traffic of the Village Express and gondola, the Meadows Magic Carpet is a comfortable area for your first ski experience.
lift.heading: Meadows Magic Carpet

lift.description:
The Gondola Magic Carpet is

where our toddlers learn to pizza pie and french fry all day long. Conveniently located right off the gondola plaza just above the Ski School, the Gondola Magic Carpet provides optimum viewing areas for parents to observe.
lift.heading: Gondola Magic Carpet

trail.description:
After passing through the

tunnel of the Meadows run, taking a hard right on the Peaks trail delivers you to the ski-in/ski-out entrance of The Peaks Resort and Golden Door Spa.

From the Peaks Resort, the Peaks trail brings you back on to the Meadows run.
trail.heading: The Peaks

trail.description:
This great learning terrain is

also the connection to the Peaks trail, one of two Magic Carpet Learning areas, Big Billies and the Sunshine Express lift.
trail.heading: Meadows

trail.description:
Ute Park is an amazing wide-

open run located under the Ute Park lift, removed from the more popular learning areas.

Great area for beginner skiers and snowboarders alike.
trail.heading: UTE Park

trail.description:
Beginner Park, located in the

solitary Ute Park area allows for the skier or rider to test their abilities in an out-of-the way location.
trail.heading: Beginner Park

trail.description:
Village Bypass is the only

beginner run off of the Village Express lift. Village Bypass is the easiest route from the top of Village Express past Gorrono Ranch and it takes you, as the name implies, around the Mountain Village core to the bottom of the Chondola and Sunshine Express Lifts.
trail.heading: Village Bypass

trail.description:
The lower Galloping Goose is

the continuation of the far-reaching Galloping Goose trail. Accessable from Sunshine Express, this run will lead you to the Big Billies restaurant.

Be aware, choosing this run will cause you to bypass the Intercept Lot parking structure.
trail.heading: Lower Galloping Goose

trail.description:
This expansive trail allows

for family fun all day long!
trail.heading: Double Cabin

trail.description:
This fun route takes you by

many of the homes of Mountain Village as well as over and under many of the bridges thorughout the area.

Be aware, choosing this run will cause you to bypass the Intercept Lot parking structure.
trail.heading: Bridges

trail.description:
This broad portion of

Sundance is the beginning of green skiing and merges with Double Cabin at the double cabins location in the middle of the run.
trail.heading: Lower Sundance

trail.description:
This short secluded run

returns you to the Sunshine Express terrain and Double Cabins run.
trail.heading: Nellie

trail.description:
This beautiful rolling gladed

area is great for beginner skiers to experience the majesty that is Prosect Bowl.

Due to rolling flats, snowboarders need to keep their speed up to avoid having to walk.

Not recommended for beginner boarders.
trail.heading: Madison

trail.description:
Little Maude is one of two

portals to the expansive Prospect Bowl terrain.

Due to rolling flats, snowboarders need to keep their speed up to avoid having to walk. Not recommended for beginner boarders.
trail.heading: Little Maude

trail.description:
May Girl is your connection to

the Linx Poma and Ute Park terrain from Prospect Bowl.

May Girl merges into Madison, which takes you to the bottom of Prospect Bowl Express.
trail.heading: May Girl

trail.description:
This incredibly scenic run

offers beginner skiers a chance to experience some of the most stunning views Telluride has to offer from one of the highest points on the mountain.

Due to flat cat track areas, this run is not recommended for beginner boarders. At 4.6 miles, this is the longest run on the mountain.
trail.heading: Galloping Goose

trail.description: Teddy's Way is the connection between Double Cabin and the Lower beginner portion of the Sundance run.
trail.heading: Teddy's Way

trail.description:
The easiest ski route into the

town of Telluride. This switchback trail runs the entire front face of the mountain.
trail.heading: Telluride Trail

trail.description:
Bail Out is the cat track below

Kant-mak-em to avoid more difficult terrain into Telluride.
trail.heading: Bail Out

trail.description:
Easy Out is the way back to

Telluride Trail and intermediate ski or snowboard access into the town of Telluride.
trail.heading: Easy Out

trail.description:
This is your last chance to pull

away from the expert terrain of the Plunge Lift. This run will bring you on to See Forever trail.
trail.heading: Last Chance

trail.description:
The name says it all! A great

wide open ridgeline trail with 360-degree, top-of-the-world views. Often groomed.
trail.heading: Upper See Forever

trail.description:
This intermediate run,

accessible from Village Express, the free Gondola and Coonskin Lift, is a route into the Mountain Village. If you stay skiers left you can also access Gorrono Ranch and the Beach.
trail.heading: Butterfly

trail.description:
Misty Maiden, the main Village Express run, will capture you with its hills, chills and thrills!

This is your primary access to the NASTAR race course.
trail.heading: Misty Maiden

trail.description:
This straight shot connects

you from See Forever to Misty Maiden, past Gorrono Ranch and into Mountain Village.
trail.heading: Hermit

trail.description:
This less-traveled route

crossing underneath the Village Express Lift meets up with Misty Maiden right above Gorrono Ranch.
trail.heading: Pick 'N' Gad

trail.description:
The top of Peek-A-Boo has

long stretches of flat terrain, great for intermediate skiers on powder days.
trail.heading: Peek-A-Boo

trail.description:
Telluride Terrain Park and

Night Park.
trail.heading: 2 Park

trail.description:
Access to the new Telluride

Terrain Park
trail.heading: 2 Park Access

trail.description:
This is the main access to the

bottom of Polar Queen Express, with an easy and more advanced route.

Boomerang leads you to the access portals of Polar Queen Express via Cake Walk and Sheridan Headwall on skiers left. Stay skiers right in order to return to Mountain Village and the bottom of Village Express and the Gondola.
trail.heading: Boomerang

trail.description:
Cake Walk is an easier

intermediate route off Boomerang to the bottom of Polar Queen Express.

If you've had second thoughts about going up Polar Queen Express, continue past the lift and Cake Walk will meet up with Lower Boomerang
trail.heading: Cake Walk

trail.description:
Ophir Loop is a mellow ride to

the bottom of Polar Queen Express with access to Apex lift on skier's right.
trail.heading: Ophir Loop

trail.description:
You won't have any once

you've stopped tumbling and sliding down Upper Happy Thought.

Lower Happy Thought is a gentle cruise to the bottom of Apex lift.
trail.heading: Lower Happy Thought

trail.description:
This wide trail is groomed

intermittenly in order natural occurance of gentle bumps for the intermediate skier and rider.
trail.heading: Dew Drop

trail.description:
This main thouroughfare of

the Polar Queen Express gives access to Dew Drop, Alta, Silver Tip, Henry's, and all the tree runs in between.

Polar Queen is also the new home for the intermediate terrain park.
trail.heading: Polar Queen

trail.description:
This short, wide double blue

run has a great pitch for the intermediate skier/rider on a powder day.
trail.heading: Alta

trail.description: This run out will take you to the Gold Hill Express (14) and Prospect Express (12).
trail.heading: Lower Woozley's Way

trail.description:
This tree island-filled runs the

entire length of the lift and gives access to the base of both Gold Hill Express and Prospect Bowl Express.
trail.heading: Magnolia

trail.description:
Sandia is a nice, long cruiser.

From the top of Prospect Bowl Express, stay skier's right and you will get spectacular views of the Terrain off Black Iron Bowl, Palmyra Peak and Gold Hill.
trail.heading: Sandia

trail.description:
This wide, easy blue run has

a long gentle upper pitch with plenty of room to practice big ski turns or perfect your snowboarding moves.
trail.heading: Upper Sundance

trail.description:
This intermediate run off

Double Cabins and Galloping Goose links back around to Lower Galloping Goose.

Be aware, choosing this run will cause you to bypass the Intercept Lot parking structure.
trail.heading: Marmot

trail.description:
Easy-Treesies and great fun

for the whole family!

There are multiple routes through these trees that all lead on to Double Cabin.
trail.heading: Enchanted Forest

trail.description:
Lookout is the intermediate

route back to the bottom of the plunge lift, with access along the way to Telluride Trail and Easy Out.
trail.heading: Lookout

trail.description:
Smuggler is an intermediate

bump run. If you survive, a refreshing drink awaits you at the Beach at Gorrono Ranch.
trail.heading: Smuggler

trail.description:
Humboldt Draw is a great

blue bump run, with little traffic and powder that lingers. A real blast on a snowboard!

NO GROOMED WAY OUT.
trail.heading: Humboldt Draw

trail.description:
This south-facing pitch

provides the more advanced intermediate skier or rider with access to Polar Queen Express.
trail.heading: Sheridan Headwall

trail.description: Henry's is a beautiful consistent pitch, generally with smaller bumps than Gold Rush or good cruising when groomed.
trail.heading: Henry's

trail.description:
Silver Tip is a short,

ungroomed run, and a great introduction to skiing in and around trees.
trail.heading: Silver Tip

trail.description:
Woozley's Way is your route

from the top of Plunge lift and Apex lift to the Polar Queen Express terrain. This run also takes you through the gate to the base of

Gold Hill Express

and Prospect Bowl

lift.
trail.heading: Woozley's Way

trail.description:
Stella is a short intermediate

pitch off of the Galloping Goose, connecting with Madison, which takes you to the bottom of Prospect Bowl Express.
trail.heading: Stella

trail.description: Milk Run is a local favorite with a wide open consistent pitch, skiing or riding right towards downtown Telluride with spectacular views of the San Sophias.
trail.heading: Milk Run

trail.description: Lower Milk run provides a winding entry into a wide open bump run to the bottom of the Coonskin Lift(7).
trail.heading: Lower Milk Run
Pandora
Coonskin

trail.description: Lower Coonskin drops off the Telluride Trail right towards the Coonskin Lift (7) and base area, usually with medium to large, well rounded bumps.
trail.heading: Lower Coonskin

trail.description: Drop off of the traverse into the Jaws! Steep rolling terrain with medium to large bumps, and gerat on powder mornings.
trail.heading: Jaws

trail.description:
Wide, steep and frequently

groomed, Bushwhacker is a long rippin' cruiser on a powder day.
trail.heading: Bushwacker

trail.description:
This split-groomed expert run

gives you the option to test your bump skills or wide-sweeping cruisers.

Either way, you've

taken the Plunge!
trail.heading: Plunge

trail.description:
This popular tree skiing area

gives you the opportunity to bail out on Last Chance or continue the adventure down to West Drain.
trail.heading: Log Pile

trail.description:
From the top of Plunge Lift (9),

this wide and consistently steep bump run is the place to prove your skills in the moguls.
trail.heading: Mammoth

trail.description:
The name speaks for itself -

this short bump run merges into Mammoth drain.
trail.heading: Joint Point

trail.description:
Beautiful southwest-facing

glade skiing.
trail.heading: Apex

trail.description:
Silver Glade starts with

Woozley’s Way then drops off to skier’s right and turns into bumps. Stay right along the trees the steeps or go further down to the left to get into open trees.
trail.heading: Silver Glade
Lower Dynamo

trail.description:
Ski right off of Prospect Bowl

Express (12) for these steep powder turns.
trail.heading: Confidence

trail.description:
Mine Shaft is Oak Street Lift's

line run. Be sure to hit the trail exiting skier's left, or you could end up on the wrong side of the river.
trail.heading: Mine Shaft

trail.description:
Upper Bail Out is your main exit

from the bottom of Plunge Lift, with the top half regularly groomed to the Bail Out trail and the bottom half ungroomed and much more challenging.
trail.heading: Upper Bail Out
North Chute

trail.description:
After successfully braving

the trees of Log Pile, West Drain is your next challenge.
trail.heading: West Drain

trail.description:
This great multi-pitch bump

run is the perfect place for the true bump-lover, home of Karen's biggest yard sale, and host for all bump competitions.
trail.heading: Lower Plunge

trail.description:
This natural half-pipe is

narrow and fun for both boarder and skier.
trail.heading: East Drain

trail.description:
Some of the best bumps on

the mountain. Stay on your game - this run travels down the entire length of the lift line.

Try the trees to

skier’s left for

some great, long

lasting snow.
trail.heading: Kant-Mak-M

trail.description:
Some of the steepest bumps

on the mountain, the Stairs will give you a run for the money.
trail.heading: Spiral Stairs

trail.description:
This narrow drop,

sandwiched between Plunge and Spiral Stairs, is the original power line into Telluride from the first power plant to ever produce alternating -current electricity.
trail.heading: Power Line

trail.description:
A great southwest-facing

gully run with sporadic trees and bumps to the bottom of Apex Lift (6).
trail.heading: Sully's

trail.description:
The Alley has great bumps

down the original Chair 6 lift line with a run-out gully that all Apex Lift terrain feeds into.
trail.heading: Allais Alley

trail.description:
This tight run will challenge

even the most accomplished bump skier, and is boxed in by great tree-skiing.
trail.heading: Zulu Queen

trail.description:
Be on your game for this double

fall line run - the crowds on the lift will be watching!
trail.heading: Giant Steps

trail.description:
From Silver Glade veer to the

left to ski the steep face of Chongos.
trail.heading: Chongos

trail.description:
Access Happy Thought

through the traverse at the top of Woozley’s Way or drop down through the trees from the access road from Gold Hill. This steep avalanche chute

is usually bumped up with a steep wall to skier's left where powder shots can be found.
trail.heading: Happy Thought

trail.description:
This perfect avalanche chute

funnels down into a very thin choke, which then opens into a fun powder field, according to

Jesse James.
trail.heading: Little Rose

trail.description:
Access this epic chute one

of two ways. 1) Through the gate at the top of Revelation Bowl Lift (15), or 2) Traverse across the top of Little Rose and Andy' s Gold, through the gate adjacent to Andy's Gold. The expert-only chute directs you away from the cliffband by taking you to the traverse to skiers right and back to Andy's Gold. You can also egress via the new goat trail traverse into Gold Hill 1.5 and into The Fans.
trail.heading: Gold Hill 1

trail.description:
Just a few short steps from

the top of Prospect Bowl Express (12), this run offers steep chute turns.
trail.heading: Crystal

trail.description:
The mini-trees of La Rosa

make for an added element in your steep-n-deep skiing.
trail.heading: La Rosa

trail.description:
Genevieve is a short walk

from the top of Prospect Bowl Express (12) for accessing a nice, steep pitch without a lot of additional effort.
trail.heading: Genevieve

trail.description: After the short hike up Bald Mountain, Jackpot offers several longer options than Audrey, leading down into the trees or down the far ridge of Bald.
trail.heading: Jackpot

trail.description: After the short hike up Bald Mountain, this first section offers deep snow on powder days.
trail.heading: Audrey
Runaway Train

trail.description:
Great glade skiing off the See

Forever trail from the top of Gold Hill Express.
trail.heading: Buzz's Glade

trail.description:
Beautiful chute skiing with a

view to match.
trail.heading: Electra

trail.description:
This wide open face gives you

the option to ski down to Gold Hill Express, or ski the gully and connect with Electra.
trail.heading: Dynamo

trail.description:
An exhibitionist's dream. Be on

your game for this amazing bump run down the lift line.
trail.heading: Millions

trail.description:
This challenging

pitch rewards

you with steep and

deep tree turns

opening up into a

powder-filled glade

Andy's Gold has the

access gate to lower

Gold Hill 1 and The

Fans.
trail.heading: Andy's Gold

trail.description:
Offloading Revelation Lift (15)

take a hard left and hike the new Gold Hill access road. Be sure to check out the NEW bridge and staircase accessing Gold Hill Chutes 9 and 10! Chutes 6 - 10 will

not be open

continually, so

check for current

information on the

signs before you

make the hike.
trail.heading: Gold Hill Chutes 6-10
Holy Cow!
Lower Village Bypass

trail.description:
This gentler descent is one of

the two areas to be groomed in Revelation and a prime area for skiing with spectacular views.
trail.heading: Silvercloud

trail.description:
This east-facing run has views

of 12,800' Ballard Mountain and 13,200' Wasatch Mountain directly across the Bear Creek expanse.
trail.heading: Majestic

trail.description: Once you've mastered the beginner bumps of Dew Drop, skier's right or Henry's is your next step in perfecting the art of bump skiing.
trail.heading: Gold Rush

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Roy Boy

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: The Fans

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Sweet Martha

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Palmyra Basin

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Bee's Run

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Liberty Bell

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Senior's

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Tram Shot

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Sunrise

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Electric Shock

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Capitol

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Calumet

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Nice Chute

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Review

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Jello's Bowl

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Alliexit

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Couloir Bouvier

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Craig's Couloir

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Mountain Quail

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Dihedral Chute

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Dihedral Face

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Lakeview

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Westlake

trail.description:
The name says it all! A great

wide open ridgeline trail with 360-degree, top-of-the-world views. Often groomed.
trail.heading: Lower See Forever
Silver Tip Trees

trail.description:
This newly opened terrain

completes the Gold Hill expansion. To access, stay left off of Revelation Lift (15) and continue up the new Gold Hill access road. Enjoy the grand vistas before skiing the 1900' vertical feet to the base of Prospect Bowl or Gold Hill lifts. The chutes will not be open continually, so check for current information on the signs before you make the hike.
trail.heading: Gold Hill Chutes 2 - 5

trail.description: Named after local legend "Captain" Jack Carey and dedicated in 2009, this advanced tree run has multiple points of entry off See Forever, and empties into West Drain.
trail.heading: Captain Jack's

trail.description:
Challenge yourself daily on

the NASTAR course, where you'll be nationally ranked against others of your same gender and age bracket. Open daily from 10:00am - 3:00pm.
trail.heading: NASTAR

trail.description:
Located at the top of Sunshine Express (10), the TopATen Nordic & Snowshoe Area offers 10km of groomed trails

with stunning

views. Guided, off-

trail snowshoe

tours are available

daily from

Eco Adventures:

970.728.7300
trail.heading: TopAten Nordic Ski Trails
Prospect Glades

trail.description: Trail
trail.heading: Wildcat

area.description: This area is Out-Of-Bounds
area.heading: CLOSED

area.description: Areas designated for slow skiing and snowboarding
area.heading: Skow Skiing

area.description: Terrain Area
area.heading: Gladed Areas
